intro: Elaphoglossum tonduzii, commonly known as the Tonduz's holly fern, is a member of the Dryopteridaceae family and is native to tropical regions of South America. It is a small, evergreen fern characterized by its delicate, lance-shaped fronds that are typically less than 30 centimeters in length. The plant produces spore-bearing soruses that are clustered on the underside of the fronds, a common feature in many fern species. It thrives in humid, shaded environments, often found in forest understories where it can receive indirect light. Due to its unique morphology and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
